title: Inside Lightning Stealer. A New Info Stealer Targeting over 30 Browsers

meta.title: A New Info Stealer Targeting over 30 Browsers

sentences.text: Cyble Research Labs recently encountered Lightning Stealer a new Info Stealer variant. An info stealer is a type of malware designed specifically to steal data from the victims system. This type of malware has emerged as a serious threat as Threat Actors use them to get initial access to corporate networks.
sentences.html: Cyble Research Labs recently encountered Lightning Stealer – a new Info Stealer variant. An info stealer is a type of malware designed specifically to steal data from the victim’s system. This type of malware has emerged as a serious threat as Threat Actors use them to get initial access to corporate networks.

sentences.text: Lightning stealer can target 30+ Firefox and Chromium-based browsers and steal crypto wallets, Telegram data, Discord tokens, and Steam users data. Unlike other info stealers, Lightning Stealer stores all the stolen data in the JSON format for exfiltration.
sentences.html: Lightning stealer can target 30+ Firefox and Chromium-based browsers and steal crypto wallets, Telegram data, Discord tokens, and Steam user’s data. Unlike other info stealers, Lightning Stealer stores all the stolen data in the JSON format for exfiltration.

sentences.text: Figure 1: Lightning Stealer C&C Panel
Lightning Stealer is a . NET-based Info Stealer. Figure 2 shows the file details.
sentences.html: Lightning Stealer is a . NET-based Info Stealer. Figure 2 shows the file details.

sentences.text: Figure 2: File information

The methods in Main()function of the malware binary (SHA 256: a2a3b6db773b95fa27501f081b03daf2a29bfb800b4efa397cc4fc59ff755368) which is ultimately responsible for stealing data have been presented in a sequential manner as per to their execution. Refer to Figure 3.
sentences.html: The methods in Main()function of the malware binary (SHA 256: a2a3b6db773b95fa27501f081b03daf2a29bfb800b4efa397cc4fc59ff755368) – which is ultimately responsible for stealing data have been presented in a sequential manner as per to their execution. Refer to Figure 3.

sentences.text: Figure 3: Main function
The malware first calls Input.GetLogGecko method. This method will return stolen passwords, cookies, and history from Firefox-based browsers upon execution.
sentences.html: The malware first calls Input.GetLogGecko method. This method will return stolen passwords, cookies, and history from Firefox-based browsers upon execution.

sentences.text: It initially identifies the Firefox-based browsers present in a system bypassing the respective browsers path in the AppData folder to the Directory.Exists() method. If this returns as True, those paths will be added to a new list for stealing data. The figure below shows the Firefox-based browsers targeted by the malware.
sentences.html: It initially identifies the Firefox-based browsers present in a system bypassing the respective browser’s path in the “AppData” folder to the Directory.Exists() method. If this returns as “True,” those paths will be added to a new list for stealing data. The figure below shows the Firefox-based browsers targeted by the malware.

sentences.text: Figure 4: Firefox-based browsers targeted by malware
Firefox-based browsers store user data in a Profiles folder under the AppData\Browser_name directory. Lightning Stealer checks this directory along with the file names mentioned below:
sentences.html: Firefox-based browsers store user data in a Profiles folder under the “AppData\Browser_name” directory. Lightning Stealer checks this directory along with the file names mentioned below:

sentences.text: key4.db: Stores the encryption keys and master password for logins.json.<crlf>logins.json: These files store the usernames and passwords.<crlf>places.sqlite: This file stores the user search history, downloads, and bookmarks data.
sentences.html:
• key4.db: Stores the encryption keys and master password for logins.json.
  • logins.json: These files store the usernames and passwords.
  • places.sqlite: This file stores the user search history, downloads, and bookmarks data.

sentences.text: It steals the browsers data only if the above files are present.
sentences.html: It steals the browser’s data only if the above files are present.

sentences.text: It first steals the data from the login.json file and looks for mozglue.dll and nss3.dll, which will be used to decrypt the login.json file. Figure 5 shows the credential-stealing functionality for Firefox-based browsers.
sentences.html: It first steals the data from the login.json file and looks for mozglue.dll and nss3.dll, which will be used to decrypt the “login.json” file. Figure 5 shows the credential-stealing functionality for Firefox-based browsers.

sentences.text: Figure 5: Stealing login credentials from Firefox based browsers
Then malware steals the cookies data from moz_cookies table in cookies.sqlite file and stores the data in the following format (refer Figure 6) :

sentences.html: The figure below shows the browser’s history stealing functionality.

sentences.text: Figure 7: Steals history on Firefox-based browsers
After stealing data from Firefox-based browsers, the malware targets Chromium-based browsers. Figure 8 shows the Chromium-based browsers targeted by the Lightning stealer.
sentences.html: After stealing data from Firefox-based browsers, the malware targets Chromium-based browsers. Figure 8 shows the Chromium-based browsers targeted by the Lightning stealer.

sentences.text: Figure 8: Chromium-based browsers targeted by Lightning Stealer

The sensitive user data, such as login credentials and cookies, stored in Chrome-based browsers are present in an encrypted form. The malware enumerates and gets the name of all files present in the Browser-name\User Data\ folder and checks for the Local State file, which stores the encrypted keys used by Chrome to decrypt the login data.
sentences.html: The sensitive user data, such as login credentials and cookies, stored in Chrome-based browsers are present in an encrypted form. The malware enumerates and gets the name of all files present in the “Browser-name\User Data\” folder and checks for the “Local State” file, which stores the encrypted keys used by Chrome to decrypt the login data.

sentences.text: If this file is present, the malware uses the DPAPI()functionto decrypt the encryption keys in the Local State file by calling Dpapi.CryptUnprotectData() function as can be seen in figure below.
sentences.html: If this file is present, the malware uses the DPAPI()functionto decrypt the encryption keys in the “Local State” file by calling Dpapi.CryptUnprotectData() function as can be seen in figure below.

sentences.text: Figure 9: Use of DPAPI
Chromium browsers store the login data in the Login Data file, a .SQLite file. The malware steals the data from the logins table present in this file and extracts the data in the following format:
sentences.html: Chromium browsers store the login data in the “Login Data” file, a .SQLite file. The malware steals the data from the logins table present in this file and extracts the data in the following format:

sentences.text: Figure 12: Stealing Credit Cards, History, and Autofill data from Chromium-based browsers

This stealer has the capability to steal data from crypto wallets present in the victims system. The wallets targeted by the stealer can be seen in the figure below. The malware targets the wallet files specific to the crypto applications mentioned in Figure 13. The malware then converts the wallet files content into Base64 and saves them into a list.
sentences.html: This stealer has the capability to steal data from crypto wallets present in the victim’s system. The wallets targeted by the stealer can be seen in the figure below. The malware targets the wallet files specific to the crypto applications mentioned in Figure 13. The malware then converts the wallet file’s content into Base64 and saves them into a list.

sentences.text: Figure 13: Targeted Crypto wallets
The malware then proceeds to steal the victims system info. Figure 14 shows the system info gathered by malware.
sentences.html: The malware then proceeds to steal the victim’s system info. Figure 14 shows the system info gathered by malware.

sentences.text: Figure 14: Stealing System Info

This malware also steals the .txt and .doc files present in the Desktop of the victims system. The malware reads the content of the file and encodes it using Base64. Then it saves the encoded data and file names on a list.
sentences.html: This malware also steals the .txt and .doc files present in the “Desktop” of the victim’s system. The malware reads the content of the file and encodes it using Base64. Then it saves the encoded data and file names on a list.

sentences.text: Figure 15: Stealing files from victims desktop

After this, the malware checks for the Telegram Desktop\tdata file in the ApplicationData folder. Instead of copying the file to a different directory for exfiltration, it loads its content in memory, encodes it, and saves it to a list.
sentences.html: After this, the malware checks for the “Telegram Desktop\tdata” file in the ApplicationData folder. Instead of copying the file to a different directory for exfiltration, it loads its content in memory, encodes it, and saves it to a list.

sentences.text: Figure 16: Stealing Telegram data
The Lightning stealer steals the Discord token from the following directory:
sentences.html: The Lightning stealer steals the Discord token from the following directory:

sentences.text: discord\\Local Storage\\leveldb
sentences.html: “discord\\Local Storage\\leveldb”

sentences.text: It retrieves a list of all files present in this directory and then starts stealing data from them.
sentences.html: It retrieves a list of all files present in this directory and then starts stealing data from them.

sentences.text: Figure 17: Stealing Discord token

The malware steals data from Steam, a video game digital distribution service. The stealer identifies the Steam installation path by checking the registry key value at HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\Software\Valve\Steam.
sentences.html: The malware steals data from Steam, a video game digital distribution service. The stealer identifies the Steam installation path by checking the registry key value at “HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\Software\Valve\Steam.”

sentences.text: The malware steals data from all the files present under the config folder.
sentences.html: The malware steals data from all the files present under the “config” folder.

sentences.text: Figure 18: Stealing user data from Steam

After this, the malware takes a screenshot of the victims screen and saves it in the AppData\Roaming\ folder named 1.png. Then, it converts the screenshot into Base64 encoded strings and saves it to a list.
sentences.html: After this, the malware takes a screenshot of the victim’s screen and saves it in the “AppData\Roaming\” folder named “1.png”. Then, it converts the screenshot into Base64 encoded strings and saves it to a list.

sentences.text: Figure 19: Taking a screenshot of the victims system
The malware stores all the stolen data in the lists shown in the figure below.
sentences.html: The malware stores all the stolen data in the lists shown in the figure below.

sentences.text: Figure 20: Storing stolen data in lists
Then it creates a file named 444.txt in the AppData\Roaming\ folder. Before writing content to this file, it converts the stolen data into JSON strings using JsonSerializer.Serialize() method.
sentences.html: Then it creates a file named “444.txt” in the “AppData\Roaming\” folder. Before writing content to this file, it converts the stolen data into JSON strings using JsonSerializer.Serialize() method.

sentences.text: Figure 21: Storing data as JSON strings
After this, the malware exfiltrates the data to the following domain:
sentences.html: After this, the malware exfiltrates the data to the following domain:

sentences.text: hxxp[:]//panels[.]xyz/Stealer/TSave
sentences.html: hxxp[:]//panels[.]xyz/Stealer/TSave

sentences.text: The body of the request is sent in JSON format, as can be seen in the figure below.
sentences.html: The body of the request is sent in JSON format, as can be seen in the figure below.

sentences.text: Figure 22: Data exfiltration

Info Stealers are adopting new techniques to become more evasive. As the information stolen by such malware is sensitive, organizations should follow good security practices. In the past, Cyble Research Labs has observed data breaches of large organizations because of such threats. We have also witnessed ransomware groups leveraging Info Stealers to gain initial network access and, eventually, exfiltrating sensitive data. Lightning Stealer is an emerging Info Stealer, and we may see variants of it emerge in the future.
sentences.html: Info Stealers are adopting new techniques to become more evasive. As the information stolen by such malware is sensitive, organizations should follow good security practices. In the past, Cyble Research Labs has observed data breaches of large organizations because of such threats. We have also witnessed ransomware groups leveraging Info Stealers to gain initial network access and, eventually, exfiltrating sensitive data. Lightning Stealer is an emerging Info Stealer, and we may see variants of it emerge in the future.

sentences.text: Avoid downloading pirated software from warez/torrent websites. The Hack Tool present on sites such as YouTube, torrent sites, etc., mainly contains such malware.<crlf>Use strong passwords and enforce multi-factor authentication wherever possible.<crlf>Turn on the automatic software update feature on your computer, mobile, and other connected devices.
sentences.html:
• Avoid downloading pirated software from warez/torrent websites. The “Hack Tool” present on sites such as YouTube, torrent sites, etc., mainly contains such malware.
  • Use strong passwords and enforce multi-factor authentication wherever possible.
  • Turn on the automatic software update feature on your computer, mobile, and other connected devices.

sentences.text: Use a reputed anti-virus and internet security software package on your connected devices, including PC, laptop, and mobile.<crlf>Refrain from opening untrusted links and email attachments without first verifying their authenticity.<crlf>Educate employees in terms of protecting themselves from threats like phishings/untrusted URLs.<crlf>Block URLs that could be used to spread the malware, e.g., Torrent/Warez.<crlf>Monitor the beacon on the network level to block data exfiltration by malware or TAs.<crlf>Enable Data Loss Prevention (DLP) Solution on the employees systems.
sentences.html:
• Use a reputed anti-virus and internet security software package on your connected devices, including PC, laptop, and mobile.
  • Refrain from opening untrusted links and email attachments without first verifying their authenticity.
  • Educate employees in terms of protecting themselves from threats like phishing’s/untrusted URLs.
  • Block URLs that could be used to spread the malware, e.g., Torrent/Warez.
  • Monitor the beacon on the network level to block data exfiltration by malware or TAs.
  • Enable Data Loss Prevention (DLP) Solution on the employees’ systems.
